facts.text: Petition No. 38 of 1959 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 38 of 1959. Petition under article 32 of the Constitution ofIndia for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 32 for quashing order of first respondent dated February 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the first respondent dated February 9, 1959, setting aside the order of the second respondent

facts.text: Material facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are number in dispute and they may be briefly stated The petitioner is a private companypany within the meaning

facts.text: Petitioner is a private company within the meaning of the Companies Act, 1956 with registered office at Kasturi Buildings, Bombay-1.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a private companypany within the meaning of the Companies Act, 1956 and has its registered office at Kasturi Buildings, Bombay -1 on March 24, 1954 and April 15, 1954,

facts.text: Petitioner entered into two contracts with Government of India on March 24, 1954 and April 15, 1954 for selling consignments of sugar.

anchor.surface_text: on March 24, 1954 and April 15, 1954, into two companytracts with the Government of India for selling to the latter two companysignements of sugar-one of 9500 Long Tons of sugar of Peruvian orgin

facts.text: First contract for 9500 Long Tons of sugar of Peruvian origin.

anchor.surface_text: of sugar-one of 9500 Long Tons of sugar of Peruvian orgin and the other of 25000 metrice Tons of sugar of companytinental origin.

facts.text: Letter of Credit opened by petitioner on 3rd April 1954 for first contract.

anchor.surface_text: The following are the particulars relating to the first companytract dated March 24, 1954, for the supply of 9500 Long Tons of sugar 3rd April Letter of Credit opened by the petitioner.

facts.text: S.S. Alba sailed from Salaverry Peru on 3rd May 1954 carrying 9782.01688 Long Tons of sugar.

anchor.surface_text: 3rd May, 1954 S. S. Alba sails from Salaverry  Peru  carrying 9782.01688 Long Tons of sugar. 26th May, 1954 The petitioner delivered to its Bankers,

facts.text: On 26th May 1954, petitioner delivered documents of title including endorsed bills of lading and invoice for Rs. 50,35,405-11-0 to Central Bank of India Limited for presentation to Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: 26th May, 1954 The petitioner delivered to its Bankers, the Central Bank ofIndia Limited, Bombay, along with the invoice for Rs. 50,35, 405-11-0 the Documents of Title  viz. the Bills of Lading duly endorsed in favour of the Government of India., Ministry of Food Agriculture

facts.text: Payment of Rs. 50,35,405-11-0 made by Government of India to petitioner's bankers on 7th June 1954 against delivery of invoice and bills of lading.

anchor.surface_text: 7th June 1954 Payment made to petitioners Bankers by the Government ofIndia against delivery of Invoice and Bills of Lading. 26 th June 1954 Date of arrival of S. S. Alba at Bombay harbour.

facts.text: S.S. Alba arrived at Bombay harbour on 26th June 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 26 th June 1954 Date of arrival of S. S. Alba at Bombay harbour. The companyresponding details -pertaining to the second companytract are as follows

facts.text: Petitioner delivered documents of title and invoices totaling Rs. 50,43,501-8-0, Rs. 22,69,800-13-0, Rs. 50,38,997-14-0 to Bank of Baroda Limited for second contract, endorsed to Government.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner delivered to its Bankers, the Bank of Baroda Limited, Bombay, along with its invoices for Rs.- 50,43,5o1-8-o, Rs. 22, 69,800-13-0, Rs. 50,38, 997-14-o respectively the Documents of Title  viz. the Bills of Lacling  duly endorsed

anchor.surface_text: V 26th 18th August, 19th August, Payment made to the July, 1954. 1954. 1954. petitioners Bankers by .the Government of India against delivery of Invoices and Bills of Lading.

facts.text: Vessels for second contract arrived at Bombay harbour in August and September 1954.

anchor.surface_text: V1 12th 3rd Septem- 9th Septem- August 1954. Date of arrival of Vessel at Bombay Harbour.

facts.text: Government of India received documents of title and paid price to petitioner before vessels arrived at Bombay harbour.

anchor.surface_text: The foregoing particulars disclose that some weeks before the vessel arrived at the Bombay harbour, i.e., when the vessels were on the high seas, the Government of India received the documents of title,

facts.text: Goods unloaded, taken delivery of, and cleared by Government of India after paying customs duties post arrival.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed after the goods reached the port, they were unloaded, taken delivery of, and cleared by the Government of India after paying the requisite customs duties to the authorities companycerned.

facts.text: For assessment year 1954-55 (April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955), Sales Tax Officer deducted price of the two sales from petitioner's turnover.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1954-55 i.e., April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955, the petitioner was assessed to sales tax by the Sales Tax Officer, Licence Circle, Division 1, Bombay. In calculating the turn-over of the petitioner,

facts.text: On January 31, 1958, first respondent (Assistant Collector of Sales Tax) issued notice under s.31 to review assessment order.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1958, the first respondent, the Assistant Collector of Sales Tax, issued a numberice to the petitioner under s. 31 of the Act proposing to review the said assessment order passed by the Sales Tax Officer.

facts.text: First respondent on February 9, 1959 set aside STO order, held sales taxable, reassessed to Rs.10,22,535-9-0.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent rejected both the companytentions and held that sales tax was payable in respect of the said two transactions. He reassessed the petitioner to a total amount of sales tax and general tax of Rs.10,22,850-12-0 less Rs. 315-3-0 already paid

facts.text: Second respondent issued notice of demand dated February 14, 1959 pursuant to first respondent's order.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to that order, the second respondent issued a numberice dated February 14, 1959. The petitioner has filed the present petition for the issue of a writ of certiorari

facts.text: Petitioner contended notice should be under s.15 not s.31 as sales disclosed to STO.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companytended before the first respondent that the numberice should have been issued, if at all, under s. 15 and number under s. 31 of the Act inasmuch as the sales had been disclosed to the Sales Tax Officer

facts.text: Court held sales took place in course of import when shipping documents delivered against payment while goods on high seas.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts narrated supra, it is seen that the petitioner, pursuant to the earlier companytracts entered into with the Government of India, delivered the shipping documents, including the bill of lading to the Government against payment when the goods were on the high seas.

facts.text: Property in goods passed to Government of India upon delivery of shipping documents against payment.

anchor.surface_text: For all the foregoing reasons we hold that the property in the goods passed to the Government of India when the shipping documents were delivered to them against payment.

issues.text: Whether the sales in question took place in the course of import of the goods into the territory of India and were not liable to sales tax under Art. 286(1)(b) of the Constitution as it stood before the Constitution (Sixth Amendment) Act, 1956?

anchor.surface_text: 1  Under Art. 286 1  b  of the Constitution, as it stood before the Constitution  Sixth Amendment  Act, 1956, the sales in question were number liable to sales tax inasmuch as they took place in the companyrse of import of the goods into the territory of India  2  the said sales were exempted

issues.text: Whether the said sales were exempted from sales tax under the explanation to Art. 286(1) of the Constitution as the goods were delivered for consumption in states other than Bombay?

anchor.surface_text: 2  the said sales were exempted from sales tax by the Bombay State under the explanation to Art. 286 1  of the Constitution, as the goods were delivered for the purpose of companysumption in States other than Bombay  3  the sales were effected outside the State of Bombay i.e., New Delhi,

issues.text: Whether the sales were effected outside the State of Bombay (i.e., New Delhi) and therefore exempted under Art. 286(1)(a) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: 3  the sales were effected outside the State of Bombay i.e., New Delhi, and therefore they were also exempted under Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution and  4  the first respondent could have only interfered with the earlier order of assessment under s. 15 of the Act within three years from the end of the assessment year 1954- 55,

issues.text: Whether the first respondent could interfere with the assessment order under s. 31 of the Act or only under s. 15 within three years from the end of the assessment year?

anchor.surface_text: 4  the first respondent could have only interfered with the earlier order of assessment under s. 15 of the Act within three years from the end of the assessment year 1954- 55, i.e., March 31, 1955, and that the said period having elapsed, he had numberpower to interfere in revision under s. 31 of the Act. The first point is the most substantial one in the case

issues.text: What does the phrase 'in the course of the import of the goods into the territory of India' convey?

anchor.surface_text: Under this Article, if the sales by the petitioner to the Government of India took place in the companyrse of the import. of the goods into the territory of India, the Bombay State would have numberpower to impose sales tax on the said sales. What does the phrase in the companyrse of the import of the goods into the territory of India companyvey ? The crucial words of the phrase are import and in the companyrse of.

issues.text: Whether the property in the goods passed to the Government of India when the shipping documents were delivered to them against payment?

anchor.surface_text: From the facts narrated supra, it is seen that the petitioner, pursuant to the earlier companytracts entered into with the Government of India, delivered the shipping documents, including the bill of lading to the Government against payment when the goods were on the high seas. ... For all the foregoing reasons we hold that the property in the goods passed to the Government of India when the shipping documents were delivered to them against payment.

holdings.text: The course of the import of the goods may be said to begin when the goods enter their import journey, i.e., when they cross the customs barrier of the foreign country and end when they cross the customs barrier of the importing country.

anchor.surface_text: The course of the import of the goods may be said to begin when the goods- enter their import journey, i.e., when they cross the customs barrier of the foreign country and end when they cross the customs barrier of the importing country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Etymological meaning of 'course' and 'import'; agrees with Patanjali Sastri CJ and Das J in State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory.

holdings.text: Sales in the State by the exporter or importer by transfer of shipping documents while the goods are beyond the customs barrier are within the exemption under Art. 286(1)(b).

holdings.text: Delivery and endorsement of the bill of lading operates as symbolical delivery of the goods and passes property if that is the intention of the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Law merchant principle; quotes Bowen LJ in Sanders Brothers v. Maclean; recognized in commercial world and Indian law.

anchor.surface_text: For all the foregoing reasons we hold that the property in the goods passed to the Government of India when the shipping documents were delivered to them against payment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Symbolical delivery via bill of lading; no contrary intention in contract or circumstances like chartering ship or non-transferable licence.

holdings.text: The sales in question must be held to have taken place in the course of the import into India and therefore they would be exempted from sales tax under Art. 286(1)(b) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the sale of the goods by the petitioner to the Government of India took place when the goods were on the high seas. That being so, the sales in question must be held

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property passed while goods on high seas (beyond customs barriers); falls under principle of sale by importer via shipping documents in course of import.

holdings.text: The order of the Assistant Collector of Sales Tax is set aside and that of the Sales Tax Officer is restored.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent to holding that sales exempt under Art. 286(1)(b); STO correctly deducted turnover.

anchor.surface_text: Sanders Brothers v. Madan Co.  1  thus at p. 341 The law as to the indorsement of bills of lading is as clear as in my opinion the practice of all European merchants is thoroughly understood. A cargo at sea while in the hands of the carrier is necessarily incapable of physical delivery.

precedents.cited_proposition: transfer of bill of lading while goods at sea operates as symbolical delivery of goods and passes property
precedents.cited_holding: The indorsement and delivery of the bill of lading operates as a symbolical delivery of cargo. Property in the goods passes by such indorsement and delivery of the bill of lading
